# Types of Societies

## How do sociologists classify societies?

__Technological sophistication:__  Generally, the greater the level of technological sophistication, the *less* a society depends on environmental fluctuations.

- Egalitarian
- Ranked
- Stratified
- State

## Types of Preindustrial Societies (cont.)

<div class="columns-2">
  
__Pastoralists__

- Animal husbandry of *domesticated* animal species
- Relatively mobile (searching for grazing land)
- Animals used for food/clothing/labor/transportation

## Types of Preindustrial Societies (cont.)

<div class="columns-2">

__Horticulturalists__

- Small patches of wild/domesticated plants; relatively simple tools, not very labor intenstive
- Supplements other subsistence strategies
- Associated with more-permanent settlements

## Types of Preindustrial Societies (cont.)

<div class="columns-2">

__Agriculturalists__

- Limited range of staple crops; surplus storage
- Larger, permanent settlements
- Craft specialists and elites (i.e., non-food-producers)

__Feudal__

- Strict socio-economic hierarchy
- Lords (wealthy landowners) and peasants (worked land and received protection in return)

## Industrial Societies {.smaller}

<div class="columns-2">

Industrial Revolution begins in 18th century, continues into the 19th century

- First steam engine in 1782
- Mechanical power replaces human/animal power

Related social changes...

- Migration to urban centers
- Migrants faced over-crowding, poor living/working conditions, and poverty
- Aspirations of upward socio-economic mobility
- "Old" money challenged by "new" money

<font size="3" color="red">__Sociology develops in this social context.__</font>

## Post-industrial Societies

<div class="columns-2">

Also called __*information societies*__

Some general features...

- Decrease in production of material goods
- Increase in production of *information* and *services*
- Access to education more important (than in an industrial society)

# Sociological Perspectives on Society

## Durkheim and Functionalism {.smaller}

<div class="columns-2">

- __Collective conscience__:  communal beliefs (similar to concept of *culture*)
- __Social integration__:  strength of ties to social groups
- __Mechanical solidarity__:  common to pre-industrial socieities; act in a mechanical fashion; strong kinship bonds and low division of labor
- __Organic solidarity__:  common to industrial societies; social order from acceptance of socioeconomic differences; high division of labor; allows groups with different values to coexist
- __Anomie__:  dissolution of society's collective conscience; associated with social change (chaos or unrest); transition from mechanical to organic solidarity

<CENTER>
<a href="http://thecrankysociologists.com/files/2013/05/durkheimRGB-qcwvhq.gif"><img src="http://thecrankysociologists.com/files/2013/05/durkheimRGB-qcwvhq.gif" alt="Cartoon of Durkheim" width="400"></a><br>From <a href="http://thecrankysociologists.com/">The Cranky Sociologist</a>
</CENTER>

</div>


## Marx and Conflict Theory {.smaller}

<div class="columns-2">

Main concepts...

- Base and superstructure:  economic system (base) dominates other aspects of society
- Class conflict
    + __Bourgeoisie__:  those that own/control means of production
    + __Proletariat__:  the laboring class
- Capitalism vs. communism
    + In capitalist systems, things used to make and transport products are owned by individual people and/or businesses, not the government

## Marx and Conflict Theory (cont.) {.smaller}

<div class="columns-2">

Main concepts...

- __Alienation__:  feeling of being isolated or divorced from society, work, or sense of self
    + Product and process of labor
    + Other workers and one's self
  - __False consciousness__:  condition in which the
beliefs, ideals, or ideology of a person are not in the person's own best interest
    + Examples:  emphasis in competition over cooperation, or of hard work being its own reward; these clearly benefit the *owners* of industry
- __Class consciousness__:  awareness of one's rank in society; a particular class must advocate for social improvements

## Weber and Symbolic Interactionsim

<div class="columns-2">

Agreed with Marx and Durkheim that industrialization could have negative effects on society

Weber viewed class as economically determined, but that *status* was determined by noneconomic factors (education, kinship, religion...).

## Weber's Concepts...

- __Rationalization__:  the idea that modern society should be built around logic and efficiency rather than morality or tradition
- The __iron cage__:  an abstract concept in which a person feels as though they are trapped by institutions and bureaucracy

# Social Constructions of Reality

## No Society Without Humans

Peter Berger's and Thomas Luckmann's (1966) *The Social Construction of Reality*

- __Habitualization__:  the idea that society is constructed by us and those before us, and it is followed like a habit
- __Institutionalization__:  the act of implanting a convention or norm into society


Robert Mertons's concept of the __*self-fulfilling prophecy*__

- An idea that becomes true when acted upon (e.g., a bank run; the "Apocalypse")

Symbolic interactionism offers perspective on cultural differences in verbal and non-verbal communication.


## Roles and Status

<div class="columns-2">

What is __*status*__ to a sociologist?
<br>
---*__One's relative social position within a group__*
<br>

- Ascribed status
    + Based on __who you are__
- Acheived status
    + Based on __what you do__

## Roles and Status (cont.)

<div class="columns-2">

What are __*roles*__?

---*Patterns of behavior that we recognize in each other that are __representative of a person's social status__*

- What role are you currently playing?
- What other roles do you play on a day-to-day basis?

## Role Performance and Identity

<div class="columns-2">

Charles Cooley's "looking-glass self"

- Similar to dramatugical analysis
- Our image of own identify depends, partially, on how we think *others* perceive us.
- We imagine how we must appear to others, then react to this speculation.
